channel.title: Radio National Breakfast - Breakfast Wrap
channel.description: Filtered feed containing only Breakfast Wrap episodes from Radio National Breakfast
channel.itunes:author: ABC Radio National

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What's at stake for the Trump-Xi meeting?
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Environment reforms in focus as parliament returns
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Russia responds to new US sanctions
item.description: Agenda-setting news coverage, breaking news and stories impacting the lives of all Australians.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: ICJ says Israel must allow UN aid into Gaza
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What the critical minerals deal means for Australia
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Unpacking Albanese's meeting with Trump
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Joyce contemplates life after Nationals
item.description:
Nationals MP Barnaby Joyce has confirmed he won't recontest the seat of New England at the next federal election.

Today, we hear from Mr Joyce amid fevered speculation that he is contemplating joining One Nation.

We also speak with a former Ukrainian prime minister as Australia's Prime Minister, Anthony Albanese, prepares to meet with US President Donald Trump.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Lord Mayor warns against Liberal 'lecturing'
item.description:
The Lord Mayor of Melbourne has warned the federal Liberal party about lecturing his state, after Opposition leader Sussan Ley spent the week in Melbourne criticising the city's crime rates. 

Today we hear from Nicholas Reece and opposition Senator Jane Hume. 

Then, cryptocurrency ATMs could be banned in Australia under new powers handed to the government agency, AUSTRAC, amid concerns they're being used for money laundering and terror financing.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Questioning the Coalition's plans to tackle crime
item.description:
The Coalition has been making a lot of noise about youth crime, particularly in Victoria, so what solutions is it offering up? Sally Sara interviews the new shadow Attorney General Andrew Wallace.

Then we hear from Pauline Hanson as One Nation surges in the polls. 

And we'll finish in Madagascar, where the military says it's in control of the country, after the nation's president was impeached while in hiding.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Key Liberal wants 'apology tour' to end
item.description:
The Liberal Party needs to end its post-election "apology tour" and "mass therapy session", according to one of its most senior frontbenchers.

In a wide-ranging speech last night, Shadow Finance Minister James Paterson warned that his party could face destruction if it adopts a Nigel Farage-style populist agenda. But Mr Paterson also rejected suggestions the Liberals should position themselves as free market teals. 

Then, an Arab-Israeli member of the Knesset worries that far-right politicians will justify returning to war in Gaza based on Hamas delays in returning Israeli hostage bodies. We hear from Aida Touma-Sliman. 

Also today, we look at Oral history. Its considered the world's oldest form of sharing knowledge and culture, and in Australia, Aboriginal people have been sharing stories this way for thousands of years.

Earlier this week, former prime minister Tony Abbott launched a new book tracing the history of Australia and questioned the reliability of oral history.

In response, Yorta Yorta man and chair of the First Nations Foundation, Ian Hamm, says "substance and an accurate record of events" are at the centre of oral history.

And in the wake of the algal bloom outbreak in South Australian waters, the state and federal governments are contributing more than $100 million to spruik this message.  

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: When will the Gaza humanitarian situation improve?
item.description:
There's jubilation in Israel over the release of all the remaining living hostages, and in Palestine, over the return of detainees from Israeli detention.

But when will the humanitarian situation in Gaza begin to improve?

We'll hear from UNICEF and head to Israel to hear from a human rights group monitoring the release of both groups. 

Then, treasurer Jim Chalmers has announced significant changes to the government's superannuation tax policy reforms. You'll find out what he has to say. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Tony Abbott on multiculturalism and Indigenous oral history
item.description:
In a wide-ranging interview, Australia's 28th Prime Minister Tony Abbott discusses Australian history, Indigenous Australian oral storytelling, multiculturalism and former PM Julia Gillard's famous misogyny speech. 

He shares his thoughts as he releases a new book exploring how democracy took shape in Australia. 

Then, Qantas says customer data has been released after almost six million customer records were stolen by a hacking group earlier this year through a third-party platform.

The airline says it's investigating what data has been released with the help of specialist cyber-security experts. 

And today, Israeli hostages and hundreds of Palestinians imprisoned by Israel will be swapped in the first phase of Donald Trump's plan for Gaza...

So how did this plan come about?

A veteran Israeli negotiator involved in the backroom dealings on this agreement will share his insights. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast: Israel and Hamas approve Gaza ceasefire and hostage deal
item.description:
The Israeli government has approved Gaza's ceasefire and hostage deal, the first phase of the US plan already agreed to by Hamas. 

Today we'll hear from the former US Middle East Envoy for Humanitarian Affairs about what the deal means for all sides, and from a former US AID official on how it will impact aid delivery in Gaza. Will it now ramp up?

Then, we learn details of an Israeli journalists conversations with Donald Trump, and what Palestinians think about other parts of the President's plan. 

We'll also wrap a big week in federal politics. 

And you'll meet Australia's most decorated Winter Paralympian... hoping to return to the slopes after nearly two decades. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Optus blame game explained
item.description:
Who knew what... and when... about the Optus triple zero outage? Those are the key questions asked this week in parliament following the disastrous outage linked to three deaths. 

We'll get clarity on the timeline, and hear from the federal government. 

Then, the French President says he will name a new prime minister in the next 48 hours. Yet he's still under pressure to follow his ex-Prime Minister out the door too. One of his Renaissance party colleagues joins us. 

In Queensland, mining giant Glencore has accepted a $600 million support package from the state and federal governments to save its ailing sites.

And we'll find out why an Australian has been hit with a 14 year prison sentence in absentia by Russia, over his role fighting in the war in Ukraine. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Two years on from October 7
item.description:
Israelis gathered across the country overnight to mark the second anniversary of the October 7 Hamas attack, which saw about 1200 people killed and 251 hostages taken.

Danny Majzner's sister,  Australian-Israeli Galit Carbone, was murdered at a Kibbutz on October 7.

Today, Mr Majzner will meet with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Minister for Foreign Affairs Penny Wong. 

Before the meeting, he spoke with Sally Sara. 

Today you will also hear from Jonathan Kuttab, a Palestinian human rights lawyer and co-founder of the Palestinian human rights group Al-Haq. 

Then, in response to recent Optus triple-zero failures, the federal government has introduced a bill to create a "Triple Zero Custodian" , who would provide oversight on Australia's emergency system to detect any issues.

But will this be enough to restore confidence in the system, particularly in regional and remote communities where finding adequate coverage and reception can be a day-to-day problem? 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Former Trump ally questions Gaza peace plan
item.description:
Former adviser to Mr Trump and US Ambassador to the UN, John Bolton tells us its "unlikely" the Gaza plan will happen. 

We hear from the former Trump ally as indirect negotiations happen in Egypt, and Jewish communities around the world begin marking the second anniversary of October 7th.

Then, France loses its fifth prime minister in less than two years - we find out what the political climate is like in Paris. 

And pressure is once again building on the federal government to address gambling harm,  more than two years after a landmark parliamentary report — also known as the "Murphy Report" — recommended sweeping reforms to tackle online gambling.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What does Hastie's exit mean for Ley's Liberals?
item.description:
The resignation of West Australian Liberal MP Andrew Hastie from the opposition frontbench opens yet another wound for the Coalition as parliament resumes this week.

Then, polls have closed in Syria, where the country is holding its first parliamentary elections since the toppling of the regime of Bashar al-Assad. We'll learn why this vote is different to what you'd expect. 

And a new round of indirect ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas begins in Egypt today, with the Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu saying he hopes to announce the release of hostages "in the coming days".

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Manchester reeling after deadly attack
item.description:
British authorities have condemned a deadly terrorist attack on a Jewish synagogue in northern England.

Two people have been killed and at least four others injured after an assailant drove a car into people outside the Manchester synagogue and then began stabbing them.

We'll head to Manchester to hear from the community. 

Then, at least five Australians are thought to be among those captured by the Israeli Defence Force from a flotilla which was bound for Gaza. We get a response to the situation from the federal government. 

And Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles touts news that Papua New Guinea's cabinet has approved a landmark defence treaty with Australia, after the two countries failed to sign the agreement last month.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What is the impact of the US government shutdown?
item.description:
It's day one of a government shutdown in the United States, and hundreds of thousands of federal workers are bracing for missed paychecks,  while government operations grind to a halt.

Meanwhile, the Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro says he's ready to declare a state of emergency amid reports the US military is drawing up options to target drug traffickers inside Venezuela. 

Then, California has signed a new bill into law requiring top AI companies to fulfil transparency requirements and report AI-related safety incidents. So could and should Australia follow suit? 

And a Senate inquiry into aged care has called for an end to the "rationing" of home care packages, and the urgent release of more to ensure Australians aren't dying while waiting. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What the latest housing scheme means for house prices?
item.description:
Has it just got easier or harder to get into the property market?

The federal government's Home Guarantee Scheme is expanding today, meaning more Australians will only need to pay a five per cent deposit on a property.

Under the changes, there will be no income limits, meaning all first-time buyers are eligible. But it comes as new figures show eight months of consistent property price growth, so will this new scheme encourage that trend? 

Then, we're once again talking about a government shutdown in the United States - so why is this the system that Washington has to navigate? 

And we'll look at a proposed merger between two of the country's largest media companies.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Is Trump's Gaza proposal a plan for peace?
item.description:
The White House has released a 20-point plan to end the ongoing war in Gaza, but is it a plan for peace?

You'll hear from the ABC's John Lyons, and two different Palestinian perspectives - Palestinian politician Mustafa Barghouthi and Gazan-American analyst Ahmed Fouad Alkhatib.

Then, a number of unregulated melatonin products sold in Australia have been found to be 400 per cent stronger than advertised,  while some had no active melatonin at all. So what's the warning to melatonin users?

And local artists, authors, and creatives are gathering at Parliament House today to speak out about the impact of artificial intelligence. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Australia's role in the space race
item.description:
Australia is the centre of the known universe this week, as world leaders in space development and research meet in Sydney for the annual International Astronautical Congress.

A new space race has begun, with billionaires Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos leading the way and the Australian government encouraging local industry to get involved.

Then, confusion remains about exactly how many Australian companies will be impacted by looming US pharmaceutical tariffs.

Last week the US President announced that from October, the US will impose a 100 per cent tariff on branded or patented pharmaceutical imports, unless a pharmaceutical company builds a manufacturing plant in the US - so what could it mean for Australian industry?

And the Prime Minister has wrapped up a visit to the UK with an address to the Labour party conference in Liverpool.

During the speech, Mr Albanese vowed to defend democracy itself while standing alongside the man he described as his "mate": British PM Sir Keir Starmer.

It comes after the Australian PM leaned into the comfort of the Commonwealth, enjoying lunch with King Charles at Balmoral Castle in Scotland.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.
